Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A novel approach to improve template-based multi-domain protein structure prediction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at North Carolina A&T State University (NC A&T) aims to obtain preliminary data to support cutting-edge research to design novel computational tools to model multi-domain protein structure. The spatial arrangement of domains is essential in understanding the functional mechanisms of a multi-domain protein. This project will also help broaden the participation in protein modeling research of students at NC A&T with a growing research enterprise.

This study aims to obtain preliminary data to design novel computational tools to enhance capabilities of template-based approaches for prediction of multi-domain proteins. Essentially, the availability of full-domain solved template structures for modeling multi-domain proteins in current PDB (Protein Data Bank) will be systematically analyzed. This systematic study to assess the availability of templates for multi-domain proteins in PDB will shed light on the extent of availability of templates for multi-domain proteins. These multi-domain proteins are generally not suitable for structure determination based on biochemical experimental techniques, and these proteins can also exhibit inter-domain flexibility, which can complicate or prevent crystallization. As a consequence, experimental determination of the structure of multi-domain proteins is often more difficult than for single domain proteins. Based on the systematic study, efforts will also be made to develop a novel strategy to identify distant or non-homologous template structures. This will be performed using complex matching based strategy. The results of the finding will significantly increase our ability to model multi-domain protein structure and will help to increase our understanding of protein complexes.


This EAGER project is funded by the Biology Directorate.

Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Prediction of multi-domain protein structure is an important problem in computational structural bioinformatics. The goal of this project was to assess the availability of solved structural template for multi-domain protein structure prediction and also to assess the performance of template-based docking approaches for prediction of multi-domain protein structure prediction.

 The project employed a similar approach to finding templates for protein-protein complexes to find templates for multi-domain protein structure prediction. In essence, a multi-domain set was constructed starting from PDB data bank that resulted in 4,431 non-redundant multi-domain proteins which were then used for further analysis. The set was then split into target and template based on the deposited date. Finally, target-template alignment was performed to measure the structural differences in binding modes with the structural alignment score. In addition, sequence and structural alignments were also performed and it was observed that it is possible to find good templates for a vast majority of multi-domain proteins.

Moreover, to investigate the usefulness of template-based docking approaches for multi-domain protein structure prediction, the approach was compared to an ab-initio docking based approach that uses rigid body docking. The results of the analysis showed that template-based docking performs better than ab-initio based approaches for multi-domain protein structure prediction.

The proposed approach lays foundation for the development of template-based docking approaches for the prediction of multi-domain protein structure prediction.

Two minority graduate students in Computational Science and Engineering were trained through participation to research tasks in the project. One graduate student also had the opportunity to visit Center for Computational Biology at the University of Kansas for three months during summer. The outcomes of the projects were disseminated through 2 journal papers and also discussed in bioinformatics courses at NCA&T State university.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2018
Modified by: Dukka B Kc

The goal of this project was to assess the availability of solved structural template for multi-domain protein structure prediction and also to assess the performance of template-based docking approaches for prediction of multi-domain protein structure prediction. In essence, a multi-domain set was constructed starting from PDB data bank that resulted in 4,431 non-redundant multi-domain proteins which were then used for further analysis. The set was then split into target and template based on the deposited date. Finally, target-template alignment was performed to measure the structural differences in binding modes with the structural alignment score. In addition, sequence and structural alignments were also performed and it was observed that it is possible to find good templates for a vast majority of multi-domain proteins. Moreover, to investigate the usefulness of template-based docking approaches for multi-domain protein structure prediction, the approach was compared to an ab-initio docking based approach that uses rigid body docking. The results of the analysis showed that template-based docking performs better than ab-initio based approaches for multi-domain protein structure prediction. The proposed approach lays foundation for the development of template-based docking approaches for the prediction of multi-domain protein structure prediction. Two minority graduate students in Computational Science and Engineering were trained through participation to research tasks in the project. One graduate student also had the opportunity to visit Center for Computational Biology at the University of Kansas for three months during summer.
